is="true">m</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">B</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">S</mi></mrow></mfrac></mfenced><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î”</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">S</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î”</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">t</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac></mfenced><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-1"><math><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mi is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub><mo is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mn is="true">4</mn><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Ï€</mi><mi is="true">Ï„</mi></mrow></mfrac><msup is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">m</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">B</mi></msub><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">V</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">m</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><msub is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">M</mi><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">B</mi></msub><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">S</mi></mrow></mfrac></mfenced><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mfenced open="(" close=")" is="true"><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î”</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">S</mi></msub></mrow><mrow is="true"><mi mathvariant="normal" is="true">Î”</mi><msub is="true"><mi is="true">E</mi><mi is="true">t</mi></msub></mrow></mfrac></mfenced><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></math></script></span> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0250" name="bbb0250" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0250"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[50]</span></span></a>, the corresponding D<sub>Na+</sub> values of the three electrodes are displayed in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>b. Specially, the discharge and charge D<sub>Na+</sub> values of V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC electrode are 48.3&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’13</sup>â€“6&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’13</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and 22.7&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’13</sup>â€“8.6&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’13</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, respectively, which is significantly higher than V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC-0.05 (19.9&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’13</sup>â€“3.6&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’13</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and 11.7&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’13</sup>â€“1.8&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’13</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup>) and V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC-0.15 (25.8&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’13</sup>â€“6.8&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’13</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and 14.4&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’13</sup>â€“2.2&nbsp;Ã—&nbsp;10<sup>âˆ’13</sup>&nbsp;cm<sup>2</sup>&nbsp;s<sup>âˆ’1</sup>) electrodes, demonstrating the faster transfer speed of sodium ion in V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>/NC electrode. During the discharge process, sodium ions continuously occupy active site of the electrode and accumulate, resulting in the gradual decrease of sodium ion <a href="/topics/chemistry/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a><span>. In the charging process, the <a href="/topics/physics-and-astronomy/diffusion-coefficient" title="Learn more about diffusion coefficient from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">diffusion coefficient</a> of sodium ion decreases step by step, which is due to Na</span></span><sup>+</sup><span> continuous extraction from the <a href="/topics/chemistry/electrode-material" title="Learn more about electrode material from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrode material</a> leading to the decrease of Na</span><sup>+</sup><span> concentration. The <a href="/topics/materials-science/dielectric-spectroscopy" title="Learn more about electrochemical impedance spectroscopy from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">electrochemical impedance spectroscopy</a> (EIS) analyses of three electrodes were measured in the range of 10</span><sup>5</sup> to 10<sup>âˆ’2</sup>&nbsp;Hz frequency. In the light of the equivalent electrical circuit, the resistance of charge transfer (<em>R</em><sub>ct</sub>) of the V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC-0.05 (16.52&nbsp;Î©), V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC (13.85&nbsp;Î©) and V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC-0.15 electrode (13.72&nbsp;Î©) are slightly lower than pure V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC electrode (30.78&nbsp;Î©) in the high frequency region, indicating the introduction of N-doped can improve electrochemical conductivity of the electrode (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Figs. 6</span></span></a>c and S5c). Furthermore, in the low frequency region, the Warburg impedance (Ïƒ<sub>Ï‰</sub>) of V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC-0.05, V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC and V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC-0.15 electrodes are 555.3, 147.2 and 484.9, respectively (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0030" name="bf0030" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0030"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 6</span></span></a>d). According to the equation <span class="math"><span class="MathJax_Preview" style=""></span><span class="MathJax_SVG" id="MathJax-Element-2-Frame" tabindex="0" data-mathml="<math xmlns=&quot;http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML&quot;><msub is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>D</mi><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi mathvariant=&quot;italic&quot; is=&quot;true&quot;>Na</mi><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>+</mo></msup></msub><mo is=&quot;true&quot;>=</mo><mfrac is=&quot;true&quot;><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>R</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msup><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>T</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow is=&quot;true&quot;><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>A</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msup><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>F</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>4</mn></msup><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>n</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>4</mn></msup><msup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>C</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msup><msubsup is=&quot;true&quot;><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C3;</mi><mi is=&quot;true&quot;>&amp;#x3C9;</mi><mn is=&quot;true&quot;>2</mn></msubsup></mrow></mfrac></math>" role="presentation" style="font-size: 90%; display: inline-block; position: relative;"><svg xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink" width="19.751ex" height="4.279ex" viewBox="0 -1094.9 8504.1 1842.1" role="img" focusable="false" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -1.735ex;"><g stroke="currentColor" fill="currentColor" stroke-width="0" transform="matrix(1 0 0 -1 0 0)"><g is="true"><g is="true"><use xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(353,0)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-41"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(530,313)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(1205,0)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-46"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(552,288)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-34"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2079,0)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-6E"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(424,204)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-34"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(2824,0)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-43"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(547,306)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g></g><g is="true" transform="translate(3692,0)"><g is="true"><use transform="scale(0.707)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C3"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(405,244)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMAIN-32"></use></g><g is="true" transform="translate(404,-106)"><use transform="scale(0.5)" xlink:href="#MJMATHI-3C9"></use></g></g></g></g></g></g></svg><span class="MJX_Assistive_MathML" role="presentation"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML"><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub><mo is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><msup is="true"><mi is="true">R</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mi is="true">T</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn><msup is="true"><mi is="true">A</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mi is="true">F</mi><mn is="true">4</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mi is="true">n</mi><mn is="true">4</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mi is="true">C</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">Ïƒ</mi><mi is="true">Ï‰</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msubsup></mrow></mfrac></math></span></span><script type="math/mml" id="MathJax-Element-2"><math><msub is="true"><mi is="true">D</mi><msup is="true"><mi mathvariant="italic" is="true">Na</mi><mo is="true">+</mo></msup></msub><mo is="true">=</mo><mfrac is="true"><mrow is="true"><msup is="true"><mi is="true">R</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mi is="true">T</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup></mrow><mrow is="true"><mn is="true">2</mn><msup is="true"><mi is="true">A</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mi is="true">F</mi><mn is="true">4</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mi is="true">n</mi><mn is="true">4</mn></msup><msup is="true"><mi is="true">C</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msup><msubsup is="true"><mi is="true">Ïƒ</mi><mi is="true">Ï‰</mi><mn is="true">2</mn></msubsup></mrow></mfrac></math></script></span> <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0240" name="bbb0240" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0240"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[48]</span></span></a>, <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bb0245" name="bbb0245" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="bb0245"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[49]</span></span></a>, the smaller the value of Ïƒ<sub>Ï‰</sub> is, the greater the value of D<sub>Na+</sub>. Therefore, it is concluded that Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion ability is preferable in the V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC electrode, which means that V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC electrode has prominent electrochemical conductivity to promote Na<sup>+</sup> transfer. More obviously, the Rct of the V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC electrode decreases significantly to 6.38&nbsp;Î© after 1700&nbsp;cycles of 0.5 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and it also demonstrates fine Na<sup>+</sup> diffusion ability in the low frequency region in Fig. S12. This means that the V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC electrode has stable electrochemical conductivity and favorable Na<sup>+</sup> kinetics. What's more, the morphology of V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC electrode after 200&nbsp;cycles at 0.5A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> was performed in Fig. S13. After cycling, the V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>/NC electrode can basically maintain the original spherical structure without serious <a href="/topics/chemistry/pulverization" title="Learn more about pulverization from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">pulverization</a> and aggregation (Figs. S13a and S14a). Even the yolk-shell structure can be observed at the damaged site, indicating that the electrode has excellent structural stability (Fig. S13b). The outstanding structural integrity of V</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC is attributed to the perfect combination of V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> and N-doped carbon, which is conducive to the electrode to carry out stable cycling and obtain an extremely long cycle life spans. Fig. S14b displays the V 2p spectrum of the V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC electrode after 200&nbsp;cycles at 0.5 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>. There are two peaks located at 523.5&nbsp;eV and 515.1&nbsp;eV in V 2p spectrum, which are attributed to the V<sup>3+</sup> 2p<sub>1/2</sub> and V<sup>3+</sup> 2p<sub>3/2</sub>, respectively, indicating the good structural stability and reversibility of V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC electrode.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0030"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23009015-gr6.jpg" height="456" alt="Fig. 6" aria-describedby="ca0030"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23009015-gr6_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (452KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (452KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23009015-gr6.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0030"><p id="sp0030"><span class="label">Fig. 6</span>. Electrochemical performances of V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC, V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC-0.05 and V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span><span>/NC-0.15 electrodes: (a) <a href="/topics/chemistry/titration" title="Learn more about GITT from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">GITT</a> curves, (b) coefficients of </span><a href="/topics/materials-science/sodium-ion" title="Learn more about sodium ion from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">sodium ion</a> for the discharge and charge process, (c) Nyquist plots based on equivalent circuit and (d) the Zâ€²&nbsp;âˆ’&nbsp;Ï‰</span><sup>âˆ’1/2</sup> plots.</p></span></span></figure></div><div class="u-margin-s-bottom"><div id="p0095">To truly evaluate the practical prospect of the yolk-shell V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC spheres, the V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> full-cell are assembled matching with Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> cathode after five cycles of activation, as the illustration shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>a. First, the Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span> was assembled into a half-cell with Na tablets for electrochemical performance evaluation. It presents overlapped CV curves in initial three cycles (Fig. S15a), the corresponding charge/discharge profiles displays high <a href="/topics/materials-science/redox-process" title="Learn more about redox reaction from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">redox reaction</a> voltage of 3.2/3.44&nbsp;V (Fig. S15b). The Na</span><sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> electrode produces steady cycling stability at 0.2 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and keeps 97.5 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> after 90&nbsp;cycles in Fig. S15c. The electrochemical performances of V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> full-cell were evaluated between 0.4 and 3.8&nbsp;V. <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>b reveals the charge/discharge curves with similar platform for the initial three cycles at 0.05 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, indicating the full cell owns stable cyclic stability. As shown in <a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>c, the fullâˆ’cell presents satisfactory rate capability, which are 41.8 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> (0.1 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>), 35.2 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> (0.2 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>), 30.1 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> (0.4 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>), 25.5 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> (0.6 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>) and 24.5 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> (0.8 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>). The cycling stability of V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> full-cell is further investigated at 0.2 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and maintained satisfactory discharge capacity: 46 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> after 300&nbsp;cycles (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#f0035" name="bf0035" data-sd-ui-side-panel-opener="true" data-xocs-content-type="reference" data-xocs-content-id="f0035"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Fig. 7</span></span></a>d). The excellent properties indicate that porous yolk-shell V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC composites are a prospect anode for SIBs.</div><figure class="figure text-xs" id="f0035"><span><img src="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23009015-gr7.jpg" height="929" alt="Fig. 7" aria-describedby="ca0035"><ol class="u-margin-s-bottom"><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23009015-gr7_lrg.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download high-res image (707KB)"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download high-res image (707KB)</span></span></span></a></li><li><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23009015-gr7.jpg" target="_blank" download="" title="Download full-size image"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Download: <span class="download-link-title">Download full-size image</span></span></span></a></li></ol></span><span class="captions text-s"><span id="ca0035"><p id="sp0035"><span class="label">Fig. 7</span>. Electrochemical performance of V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub><span> full-cell: (a) the diagram of full <a href="/topics/chemistry/battery-electrochemical-energy-engineering" title="Learn more about battery from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">battery</a>. (b) GCD curves, (c) rate capability, and (d) cycle performance at 0.2 A g</span><sup>âˆ’1</sup>.</p></span></span></figure></div></section><section id="s0030"><h2 id="st0055" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">4. Conclusion</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0100">In summary, we used a facile solvothermal-carbonization method to prepare porous yolk-shell V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC spheres for efficient and steady sodium ion storage. The porous yolk-shell V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub><span>/NC spheres have diverse merits: nanoparticles as primary building block can provide a convenient way for ion/electron transport, thus speeding up ion/electron transport; unique yolk-shell spheres can conduce to tolerate volume changes during discharge/charge reaction to obtain robust structural stability; nitrogen-doped carbon improves overall electrochemical conductivity of the electrode; abundant <a href="/topics/chemistry/meso-porosity" title="Learn more about mesoporous from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">mesoporous</a> as well as great BET specific surface can boost electrolyte penetration and provide plentiful active sites, thus enhancing reaction kinetics. Therefore, the porous yolk-shell V</span><sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC spheres exhibit outstanding cycling stability (129.5 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 5.0 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> over 12,000 ultraâˆ’long cycles). What's more, V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>/NC//Na<sub>3</sub>V<sub>2</sub>(PO<sub>4</sub>)<sub>3</sub> full-cell also shows unprecedented cycle life (300&nbsp;cycles) and satisfactory capacity (46 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>) at 0.2 A g<sup>âˆ’1</sup><span>, demonstrating its potential for practical applications. This work provides a rational strategy (structural engineering and <a href="/topics/chemistry/phase-composition" title="Learn more about composition from ScienceDirect's AI-generated Topic Pages" class="topic-link">composition</a> recombination) to modify electrode materials to acquire long-life cycle property for sodium ion storage.</span></div></section><section id="s0035"><h2 id="st0060" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">CRediT authorship contribution statement</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0105"><strong>Lixin Li:</strong> Conceptualization, Methodology, Investigation, Writing â€“ original draft, Writing â€“ review &amp; editing. <strong>Chao Wang:</strong> Supervision. <strong>Chunhong Zhang:</strong> Funding acquisition, Supervision, Writing â€“ review &amp; editing. <strong>Xianqi Cao:</strong> Visualization. <strong>Jianwei Bai:</strong> Visualization. <strong>Ruiqi Li:</strong> Supervision.</div></section></div><section id="coi0005"><h2 id="st0065" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Declaration of competing interest</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0110">The authors declare that they have no known competing financial interests or personal relationships that could have appeared to influence the work reported in this paper.</div></section><section id="ac0005"><h2 id="st0070" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Acknowledgements</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0115">This work was financially supported by the&nbsp;<span id="gts0020">Fundamental Research Funds for the Central Universities</span>, China (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gts0020"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">3072022QBZ2703</span></span></a>), <span id="gts0010">Natural Science Foundation of Heilongjiang Province</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gts0010"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">LH2022E045</span></span></a>), <span id="gts0015">University and Local Integration Development Project of Yantai</span> (<a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#gts0015"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">2022 XDRHXMXK08</span></span></a>).</div></section><div class="Appendices"><section id="s0040"><h2 id="st0075" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Appendix A. Supplementary data</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0120"><span class="display"><span class="e-component e-component-mmc1" id="ec0005"><span class="article-attachment u-margin-xs-bottom"><a class="anchor download-link u-font-sans anchor-primary anchor-icon-left anchor-with-icon" href="https://ars.els-cdn.com/content/image/1-s2.0-S2352152X23009015-mmc1.docx" target="_blank" download="" id="st0025" class="u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">Data availability</h2><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="p0030">Data will be made available on request.</div></section></div><div class="Tail"></div><div><section class="bibliography u-font-serif text-s" id="bi0005"><h2 class="section-title u-h4 u-margin-l-top u-margin-xs-bottom">References</h2><section class="bibliography-sec" id="bs0005"><ol class="references" id="reference-links-bs0005"><li><span class="label u-font-sans"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="#bbb0005" id="ref-id-bb0005" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=references:type=anchor:name=citation-name"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">[1]</span></span></a></span><span d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div><div class="ReferenceLinks u-font-sans"><span class="link lazy-third-party-pdf-link"><span></span></span><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://www.scopus.com/inward/record.url?eid=2-s2.0-85110481139&amp;partnerID=10&amp;rel=R3.0.0" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-rf202304250534184534"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">View in Scopus</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a><a class="anchor link anchor-primary" href="https://scholar.google.com/scholar_lookup?title=Ti3C2Tx%20MXene%20conductive%20layers%20supported%20bio-derived%20Fex1SexMXenecarbonaceous%20nanoribbons%20for%20high-performance%20halffull%20sodium-ion%20and%20potassium-ion%20batteries&amp;publication_year=2021&amp;author=J.M.%20Cao&amp;author=L.L.%20Wang&amp;author=D.D.%20Li&amp;author=Z.Y.%20Yuan&amp;author=H.%20Xu&amp;author=J.Z.%20Li&amp;author=R.Y.%20Chen&amp;author=V.%20Shulga&amp;author=G.Z.%20Shen&amp;author=W.%20Han" target="_blank" rel="noopener noreferrer" aria-describedby="ref-id-rf202304250534184534"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Google Scholar</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></div></span></li></ol></section></section></div><div id="section-cited-by"><section aria-label="Cited by" class="ListArticles preview"><div class="PageDivider"></div><header id="citing-articles-header"><h2 class="u-h4 u-margin-l-ver u-font-serif">Cited by (12)</h2></header><div aria-describedby="citing-articles-header"><div class="citing-articles u-margin-l-bottom"><ul><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-0-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S240582972400727X"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Advanced carbon sphere-based hybrid materials produced by innovative aerosol process for high-efficiency rechargeable batteries</span></span></a></h3><div>2025, Energy Storage Materials</div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-0-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-0" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="spara032">Recent interest in designing advanced functional nanostructured hybrid materials with superior electrochemical properties has increased, particularly for energy storage applications. Carbon sphere-based hybrid materials are promising for high-performance electrodes in rechargeable batteries (e.g., lithium-ion batteries, sodium-ion batteries) owing to their high chemical stability and electrical conductivity. These properties facilitate effective electron/ion transfer paths in electrodes, leading to enhanced battery performance. Carbon spheres also mitigate unwanted side reactions, improving Coulombic efficiency and allowing for tuning of surface characteristics to achieve high capacity. Aerosol spray techniques enable homogeneous mixing of precursor components at the molecular level in the spray solution, offering a cost-effective and continuous process for preparing multicomponent materials with desired structures. Despite these advancements, there is a lack of specialized reviews on the development of carbon sphere-based hybrid materials for rechargeable batteries. This review addresses this gap by investigating recent progress in the aerosol-based synthesis of nanostructured carbon sphere-based hybrid electrode materials for rechargeable battery applications. Beginning with a brief introduction to the working principles of spray processes, then discuss recent experimental achievements in overcoming challenges like low specific capacity, unsatisfactory Coulombic efficiency, and poor rate performance. The review concludes by summarizing the current status and exploring future prospects of these materials synthesized using aerosol spray techniques, providing insights and inspiration for developing next-generation high-performance rechargeable batteries.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-1-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S2352152X24015032"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Nitrogen-doped carbon confined V&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;O&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt; with 3D porous network structure for high performance Na&lt;sup&gt;+&lt;/sup&gt; and K&lt;sup&gt;+&lt;/sup&gt; storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Energy Storage</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">However, their further development and application are limited by the scarcity of lithium resources. With the proposal of initiatives for carbon neutrality, the development of alternatives to LIBs raises vigorous concerns [1â€“3]. In nature, Na, K, and Li have similar chemical properties, while the element abundance of Na (2.6 %) and K (2.4 %) in the earth's crust is higher than that of Li (0.002 %), which makes them more economical and sustainable.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-1-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-1" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0040">Vanadium trioxide (V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>) has become a promising anode material for electrochemical Na<sup>+</sup>/K<sup>+</sup> storage due to its high theoretical specific capacity and conductivity. However, the performance of V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> is threatened due to sluggish electrons/ion transportation and tremendous structural change during the cycle process. Herein, a homogeneous 3D porous V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> and N-doped carbon composite (p-V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NC) was rationally designed and prepared by a combined approach of the template-assisted sol-gel and calcination process. Notably, no apparent shape or size of V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> was embedded into the N-doped carbon 3D network architecture, which can better adapt to the volume changes during the repeated ions intercalation/deintercalation process. In addition, the electrochemical properties were improved by the accessible area of ions and efficient ion/electron transportation paths in the interconnected 3D multilevel porous network. As expected, the p-V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NC anode delivers good rate performance and cycling stability. At a current density of 0.05&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, the p-V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NC anode exhibits a reversible specific capacity of 260&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> and 350.5&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for K<sup>+</sup> and Na<sup>+</sup> storage, respectively. Even at 1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, the reversible capacities of Na<sup>+</sup> for 110.7&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> after 900&nbsp;cycles and 123&nbsp;mAh&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> for K<sup>+</sup> after 1000&nbsp;cycles can be achieved. This work presents a simple and effective strategy to prepare a 3D-integrated porous heteroatom-doped carbon/V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> composite and it also offers a reference for constructing homogeneous porous composites.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-2-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="/science/article/pii/S0925838823038252"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Hollow spheres of Co-doped V&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;O&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt; enveloped in N-doped carbon as efficient anode for sodium-ion storage</span></span></a></h3><div>2024, Journal of Alloys and Compounds</div><div class="CitedSection u-margin-s-top"><div class="u-margin-s-left"><div class="cite-header u-text-italic u-font-sans">Citation Excerpt :</div><p class="u-font-serif text-xs">In Fig. 3e, Co-V2O3@NC demonstrates a high charge capacity of âˆ¼260 mAh gâˆ’1 at the initial cycles, and it holds specific capacity of approximate 240 mAh gâˆ’1 after 1000 cycles, showing the remarkably stable cycle performance with high capacity retention of over 92 %. As compared in Table S1, the designed Co-V2O3@NC exhibits good electrochemical sodium storage properties of high specific capacity and rate performance that are comparable to those reported vanadium oxides based anodes, including VO2 microspheres [33], VO2 nanobelts [34], oxygen-deficient V2O3@NC [35], V2O3@N-doped carbon nanorods [42], V2O3/carbon nanofibers [43], V2O3/NC hollow spheres [49], and V2O3/black fungus-derived carbon NC [50], which are close to the best samples of metastable V2O3@NC [36], multi-shelled V2O3/C [37], and yolk-shell V2O3/NC [48]. The CV curves at varied sweep rates (0.2â€“1.0 mV sâˆ’1) are collected to determine the quantitative capacitive effects of Co-V2O3@NC electrode, which could reflect the electrochemical kinetics and surface capacitive sodium storage behavior.</p></div></div></div><div class="buttons"><button class="button-link button-link-primary button-link-icon-right" type="button" data-aa-button="sd:product:journal:article:location=citing-articles:type=view-details" aria-describedby="citing-articles-article-2-title" aria-controls="citing-articles-article-2" aria-expanded="false"><span class="button-link-text-container"><span class="button-link-text">Show abstract</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 92 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-down"><path d="M1 51l7-7 38 38 38-38 7 7-45 45z"></path></svg></button></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"><div class="u-margin-ver-m"><div class="u-margin-s-bottom" id="sp0030">Vanadium oxides are potential anode materials for sodium-ion batteries, however, their application is limited for their rate capability and cycle life. Herein, hollow spheres of Co-doped V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> enveloped in N-doped carbon (Co-V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NC) are prepared through a hydrothermal step with the following sintering process. The hollow spherical structure supplies short distance and large area for fast ion transfer kinetics, which also provides voids to ease the volume expansion. The strong coupling between Co-V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub> nanoparticles and carbon layer constitutes a solid structure that enhances the conductivity and keeps electrode integrity. Co-doping introduces plenty of active sites for surface capacitance behavior and accelerates charge transfer. On account of the benefits, Co-V<sub>2</sub>O<sub>3</sub>@NC exhibits excellent Na<sup>+</sup> storage properties as anode, including high capacity of 338.5 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> at 0.1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, stable cycling capability of 240 mAh g<sup>âˆ’1</sup> after 1000 cycles at 1&nbsp;A&nbsp;g<sup>âˆ’1</sup>, and excellent rate performance. This work describes the importance of constructing specific structured materials for advanced anodes.</div></div></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-3-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1149/2162-8777/ad5b87" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Production of Sulphur-Doped Graphene Oxide as an Anode Material for Na-Ion Batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2024, ECS Journal of Solid State Science and Technology</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-4-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1021/acs.langmuir.3c03876" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Recent Progress on Porous Carbons for Carbon Capture</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2024, Langmuir</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li><li class="ListArticleItem u-margin-l-bottom"><div class="sub-heading u-margin-xs-bottom"><h3 class="u-font-serif" id="citing-articles-article-5-title"><a class="anchor anchor-primary" href="https://doi.org/10.1002/batt.202300391" target="_blank"><span class="anchor-text-container"><span class="anchor-text">Flower-like Hierarchical Ti&lt;inf&gt;3&lt;/inf&gt;C&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;T&lt;inf&gt;x&lt;/inf&gt;@MoS&lt;inf&gt;2&lt;/inf&gt;/Nitrogen-doped Carbon Composite as High-performance Anodes for Sodium-ion Batteries</span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens in new window" class="icon icon-arrow-up-right-tiny arrow-external-link"><path d="M1.12949 2.1072V1H7V6.85795H5.89111V2.90281L0.784057 8L0 7.21635L5.11902 2.1072H1.12949Z"></path></svg></span></a></h3><div>2024, Batteries and Supercaps</div></div><div class="buttons"></div><div class="u-display-none" aria-hidden="true"><div class="abstract u-margin-xs-top u-margin-m-bottom u-font-serif" id="reference-abstract"></div></div></li></ul><a class="button-alternative button-alternative-secondary large-alternative button-alternative-icon-left" href="http://www.scopus.com/scopus/inward/citedby.url?partnerID=10&amp;rel=3.0.0&amp;eid=2-s2.0-85153569903&amp;md5=349efc2b19d01d25f6f3a484b9ae9" target="_blank" id="citing-articles-view-all-btn"><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 54 128" height="20" class="icon icon-navigate-right"><path d="M1 99l38-38L1 23l7-7 45 45-45 45z"></path></svg><span class="button-alternative-text-container"><span class="button-alternative-text">View all citing articles on Scopus</span></span><svg focusable="false" viewBox="0 0 8 8" height="20" aria-label="Opens     const pendoData = {"visitor":{"pageName":"SD:product:journal:article","pageType":"CP-CA","pageProduct":"SD","pageLanguage":"en","pageEnvironment":"prod","accessType":"ae:ANON_IP","countryCode":"GB"},"account":{"id":"ae:11279","name":"ae:Imperial College London"},"events":{}};;
    pendoData.events = {
      ready: function () {
        pendo.addAltText();
      },
    };
    function runPendo(data, options) {
  const {
    firstDelay,
    maxRetries,
    urlPrefix,
    urlSuffix,
    apiKey
  } = options;
  (function (apiKey) {
    (function (p, e, n, d, o) {
      var v, w, x, y, z;
      o = p[d] = p[d] || {};
      o._q = [];
      v = ['initialize', 'identify', 'updateOptions', 'pageLoad'];
      for (w = 0, x = v.length; w < x; ++w) (function (m) {
        o[m] = o[m] || function () {
          o._q[m === v[0] ? 'unshift' : 'push']([m].concat([].slice.call(arguments, 0)));
        };
      })(v[w]);
      y = e.createElement(n);
      y.async = !0;
      y.src = urlPrefix + apiKey + urlSuffix;
      z = e.getElementsByTagName(n)[0];
      z.parentNode.insertBefore(y, z);
    })(window, document, 'script', 'pendo');
    pendo.addAltText = function () {
      var target = document.querySelector('body');
      var observer = new MutationObserver(function (mutations) {
        mutations.forEach(function (mutation) {
          if (mutation?.addedNodes?.length) {
            if (mutation.addedNodes[0]?.className?.includes("_pendo-badge")) {
              const badge = mutation.addedNodes[0];
              const altText = badge?.attributes['aria-label']?.value || 'Feedback';
              const pendoBadgeImage = pendo.dom(`#${badge?.attributes?.id.value} img`);
              if (pendoBadgeImage.length) {
                pendoBadgeImage[0]?.setAttribute('alt', altText);
              }
            }
          }
        });
      });
      var config = {
        attributeFilter: ['data-layout'],
        attributes: true,
        childList: true,
        characterData: true,
        subtree: false
      };
      observer.observe(target, config);
    };
  })(apiKey);
  (function watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay, retryAttempt) {
    if (data.visitor.id) {
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else if (typeof pageDataTracker === 'object' && typeof pageDataTracker.getVisitorId === 'function' && pageDataTracker.getVisitorId()) {
      data.visitor.id = pageDataTracker.getVisitorId();
      console.debug(`initializing pendo`);
      pendo.initialize(data);
    } else {
      if (retryAttempt > 0) {
        return setTimeout(function () {
          watchAndSetPendo(nextDelay * 2, retryAttempt - 1);
        }, nextDelay);
      }
      pendo.initialize(data);
      console.debug(`gave up ... pendo initialized`);
    }
  })(firstDelay, maxRetries);
}
    window.addPendoScript = () => {
      runPendo(pendoData, {
        firstDelay: 100,
        maxRetries: 5,
        urlPrefix: 'https://cdn.pendo.io/agent/static/',
        urlSuffix: '/pendo.js',
        apiKey: 'd6c1d995-bc7e-4e53-77f1-2ea4ecbb9565',
      });
      window.addPendoScript = () => {};
    };
    addEventListener('load', () => window.addPendoScript());
  </script>
